records.title: Taiwan Aboriginal Jacket

records.creditline: Harvard Art Museums/Arthur M. Sackler Museum, Gift of Mrs. Simon Kuznets
records.verificationleveldescription: Good. Object is well described and information is vetted

images.copyright: President and Fellows of Harvard College
President and Fellows of Harvard College
President and Fellows of Harvard College

records.description: This waist-length jacket has straight sides with a short vent on either side; a high neck with a short, standing collar; and wrist-length sleeves of even width from shoulder to wrist.  The jacket opens down the front and is secured by three spherical brass buttons that fit through corresponding loops.  The silk ground of the brocade is a light rust color; the designs of dragons and cranes amid clouds above rocks and waves are woven in threads of various colors, including gold-colored metallic ones.  The jacket is trimmed in light and dark green and it is fully lined.  The heavy brocade and the full lining indicate that this jacket was for use during cool seasons.
records.title: Woman's Jacket with Decoration of a Dragon and Crane and Clouds above Rocks and Waves
records.provenance: Mrs. Simon Kuznets purchased at an antique store in Beijing (Summer 1946).
records.dimensions: H. 70.5 x W. (across sleeves) 152.4 cm (27 3/4 x 60 in.)

records.creditline: Harvard Art Museums/Arthur M. Sackler Museum, Gift of Mrs. Simon Kuznets
records.verificationleveldescription: Good. Object is well described and information is vetted
records.description: The short, knee-length man's robe has slightly flaring sides; a high but collarless neck; and tapering, wrist-length sleeves that narrow in width from the shoulders to the wrists.  The robe opens down the front and is secured by five spherical brass buttons that fit through corresponding loops; the buttons begin at the neck and continue down to the waist.  The black silk of the robe is woven with openwork roundels depicting pairs of dragons chasing flaming pearls amid cloud and scrolling lotus designs.  There is a so-called Mandarin square, or badge of rank, on the front of the robe and an identical one on the back, indicating that this was the robe of a government official.  The embroidered squares depict a white bird with a long, plumed tail, and with wings spread in flight, ascending toward teh red disk of the sun in the upper left of the composition; the scene is set against a patterned ground that suggests rocks and waves at the bottom, clouds at the top, a pine at the left, and bamboo at the right.  The patterned ground was probably machine produced.  The brid and the sun disk were produced separately and stiched onto the patterned ground, indicative of late nineteenth or early twentieth-century workmanship, as earlier Mandarin squares tend to have the complete design integrally embroidered.  The sheer fabric and the lack of a lining indicate that the robe was for use in the summer.
records.medium: Black silk with mandarin squares embroidered in brightly colored silk threads
records.title: Short Summer Robe with Mandarin Squares on the Front and Back
records.provenance: Mrs. Simon Kuznets purchased at an antique store in Beijing (Summer 1946).
records.dimensions: H. 112.4 x W. (across sleeves) 145.6 cm (44 1/4 x 57 5/16 in.)
